editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Acted at the private house in the black friars, and publicly at the globe by the King's majesty's servants.
London, printed for H. Seile, and are to be sold at the tiger's head in saint Paul's churchyard. 1629.

list.head: The names of such as acted.

div.head: To my worthily respected friends, Nathaniel Finch, John ford, esquires; mt. Henry blunt, Mr. Robfrt Ellice, and all the rest of the noble society of Gray's inn.
div.p:
The account of some leisurable hours, is here summed up, and offered to examination. Importunity of others, or opinion of mine own, hath not urged on any confidence of running the hazard of a censure. As plurality hath reference to a multitude, so, I care not to please many: but where there is a parity of condition, there the freedom of construction, makes the best musics. This concord hath equally held between you the patrons, and me the presenter. I am cleared of all scruple of disrespect on your parts; as I am of too slack a merit in myself. My presumption of coming in print in this kind, hath hitherto been unreprovable. This piece, being the first, that ever
courted reader; and it is very possible, that the like compliment with me, may soon grow out of fashion. A practice of which that I may avoid now, I commend to the continuance of your loves, the memory of his, who without the protestation of a service, is readily your friend,

div.head: To my honoured friend, master John ford, on his lover's melancholy.
div.l: If that thou think'st these lines thy worth can raise,
Thou dost mistake: my liking is no praise:
Nor can I think thy judgement is so ill,
To seek for bays from such a barren quill:
Let your true critic, that can judge and mend,
Allow thy scenes and style: ay, as a friend
That knows thy worth, do only stick my name,
To show my love, not to advance thy fame.

div.head: To his worthy friend, the author, master John ford.
div.l: I write not to thy play: I'll not begin
To throw a censure upon what hath been
By th' best approved; it can nor fear, nor want
The rage, or liking of the ignorant.
Nor seek I fame for thee, when thine own pen
Hath forced a praise long since, from knowing men.
I speak my thoughts, and wish unto the stage
A glory from thy studies; that the age
may be indebted to thee, for reprieve
Of purer language, and that spite may grieve
To see itself outdone. When thou art read,
The theater may hope arts are not dead,
Though long concealed; that poet-apes may fear
To vent their weakness, mend, or quite forbear.
This I dare promise; and keep this in store;
As thou hast done enough, thou canst do more.

div.head: To the author, master John ford.
div.l: Black choler, reason's overflowing spring,
Where thirsty lover's drink, or any thing,
Passion, the restless current of dull plaints
Affords their thoughts, who deem lost beauties, saints:
Here their best lectures read, collect, and see
Various conditions of humanity
Highly enlightened by thy muse's rage;
Yet all so couched, that they adorned the stage.
Shun Photion's blushes thou; for sure to please
It is no sin, then what is thy disease?
Judgements applause? effeminated smiles?
Study's delight? thy wit mistrust beguiles:
Established fame will thy physician be,
(Write but again) to cure thy jealousy.

div.head: Of the lover's melancholy.
div.l: 'Tis not the language, nor the fore-placed rhymes
Of friends, that shall commend to after-times
The lover's melancholy: its own worth
Without a borrowed praise, shall set it forth.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: To tell ye (Gentlemen) in what true sense
The writer, actors, or the audience
Should mould their judgements for a play, might draw
Truth into rules, but we have no such law.
Our writer, for himself would have ye know,
That in his following scenes, he doth not owe
To others fancies, nor hath lain in wait
For any stolen invention, from whose height
He might commend his own, more than the right
A scholar claims, may warrant for delight.
It is art's scorn, that some of late have made
The noble use of poetry a trade.
For your parts (Gentlemen) to quite his pains,
Yet you will please, that as you meet with strains
Of lighter mixtures, but to cast your eye
Rather upon the main, then on the bye.
His hopes stand firm, and we shall find it true,
The lover's melancholy cured by you.

div.head: Actus. i. Scaena i.

sp.speaker: Menaphon.
sp.l: Dangers? How mean you dangers? that so courtly
You gratulate my safe return from dangers?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: From travails (Noble sir.)

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: These are delights,
If my experience hath not truant-like
Misspent the time, which I have striven to use,
For bettering my mind with observation.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: As I am modest, I protest 'tis strange:
But is it possible?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: To bestride
The frothy foams of Neptune's surging waves,
When blustering Boreas tosseth up the deep,
And thumps a thunder bounce?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Sweet sir, 'tis nothing,
Straight comes a dolphin playing near your ship,
Heaving his crooked back up, and presents
A featherbed, to waft 'ee to the shore,
As easily as if you slept i'th i'th'court.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Indeed, is't true, I pray?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I will not stretch
Your faith upon the teinters, prithee Pelias,
Where didst thou learn this language?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: I this language?
Alas, sir, we that study words and forms
Of compliment, must fashion all discourse,
According to the nature of the subject.
But I am silent, now appears a sun,
Whose shadow I adore.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My honoured father.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: From mine eyes, son, son of my care, my love,
The joys that bid thee welcome, do too much speak me a child.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: O princely sir, your hand.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Perform your duties where you owe them first,
I dare not be so sudden in the pleasures,
Thy presence hath brought home.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Here thou still findest
A friend as noble (Menaphon) as when
Thou leftest at thy departure.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes, I know it,
To him I owe more service. —

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Pray give leave,
He shall attend your entertainments soon,
Next day, and next day, for an hour or two,
I would engross him only.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Noble lord.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: You're both dismissed.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Your creature, and your servant.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, I will not say, thou'rt welcome,
That is the common road of common friends,
I am glad I have thee here — oh, I want words
To let thee know my heart.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: 'Tis pieced to mine.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis, as firmly, as that holy thing
Called friendship can unite it. Menaphon,
My Menaphon: now all the goodly blessings,
That can create a heaven on earth, dwell with thee.
Twelve months we have been sundered, but henceforth
We never more will part, till that sad hour,
In which death leaves the one of us behind,
To see the others funerals performed.
Let's now a while be free. How have thy travails
Disburdened thee abroad of discontents?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Such cure as sick men find in changing beds,
I found in change of airs; the fancy flattered
My hopes with ease, as theirs do, but the grief
Is still the same.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Such is my case at home.
Cleophyla, thy kinswoman, that maid
Of sweetness and humility, more pities
Her father's poor afflictions, than the tide
Of my complaints.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Thamasta, my great mistress,
Your princely sister, hath, I hope ere this,
Confirmed affection on some worthy choice.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Not any, Menaphon. Her bosom yet
Is intermured with ice, though by the truth
Of love, no day hath ever passed, wherein
I have not mentioned thy deserts, thy constancy
Thy — come, in troth I dare not tell thee what,
Lest thou mightst think I fawned upon a sin
Friendship was never guilty of; for flattery
Is monstrous in a true friend.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Does the court
Wear the old looks too?

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: If thou meanest the prince,
It does, he's the same melancholy man,
He was at's father's death, sometimes speaks sense,
But seldom mirth; will smile, but seldom laugh;
Will lend an ear to business, deal in none;
Gaze upon revels, antic fopperies,
But is not moved; will sparingly discourse,
Hear music; but what most he takes delight in,
Are handsome pictures; one so young, and goodly,
So sweet in his own nature, any story
Hath seldom mentioned.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why should such as I am,
Groan under the light burdens of small sorrows,
Whenas a prince, so potent, cannot shun
Motions of passion? To be man (My lord)
Is to be but the exercise of cares
In several shapes; as miseries do grow,
They alter as men's forms; but how, none know.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: This little I'll of Cyprus sure abounds
In greater wonders, both for change and fortune,
Than any you have seen abroad.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Then any
I have observed abroad: all countries else
To a free eye and mind yield something rare;
And I for my part, have brought home one jewel.
Of admirable value.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: Jewel, Menaphon?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: A jewel, my Amethus, a fair youth;
A youth, whom if I were but superstitious,
I should repute an excellence more high,
Then mere creations are, to add delight.
I'll tell ye how I found him.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: Prithee do.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Passing from Italy to Greece, the tales
Which poets of an elder time have feigned
To glorify their Tempe, bred in me
Desire of visiting that paradise.
To Thessaly I came, and living private,
Without acquaintance of more sweet companions ▪
Than the old inmates to my love, my thoughts;
I day by day frequented silent groves,
And solitary walks. vide Famistradam. lib. 2. Prolas. 6. Acad. 3. Imitat. Claudian. one morning early
This accident encountered me: I heard
The sweetest and most ravishing contention,
That art or nature ever were at strife in.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: I cannot yet conceive, what you infer
By art and nature.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I shall soon resolve ye.
A sound of music touched mine ears, or rather
Indeed entranced my soul: as I stole nearer,
Invited by the melody, I saw
This youth, this fair-faced youth, upon his lute
With strains of strange variety and harmony,
Proclaiming (As it seemed) so bold a challenge
To the clear quiristers of the woods, the birds,
That as they flocked about him, all stood silent,
Wondering at what they heard. I wondered too.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: And so do I, good, — on.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: A nightingale.
Nature's best skilled musician undertakes
The challenge, and for every several strain
The well-shaped youth could touch, she sung her down;
He could not run division with more art
Upon his quaking instrument, than she,
The nightingale did with her various notes
Reply too, for a voice, and for a sound,
Amethus, 'tis much easier to believe
That such they were, then hope to hear again.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: How did the rival's part?

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: You term them rightly,
For they were rivals, and their mistress harmony.
Some time thus spent, the young man grew at last
Into a pretty anger, that a bird
Whom art had never taught cliffs, moods, or notes,
Should vie with him for mastery, whose study
Had busied many hours to perfect practice:
To end the controversy, in a rapture,
Upon his instrument he plays so swiftly,
So many voluntaries, and so quick,
That there was curiosity and cunning,
Concord in discord, lines of differing method
Meeting in one full centre of delight.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: Now for the bird.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: The bird ordained to be
Music's first martyr, strove to imitate
These several sounds: which, when her warbling throat
Failed in, for grief, down dropped she on his lute,
And broke her heart; it was the quaintest sadness,
To see the conqueror upon her hearse,
To weep a funeral elegy of tears,
That trust me (My Amethus) I could chide
Mine own unmanly weakness, that made me
a fellow-mourner with him. Amet. I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: He looks upon the trophies of his art,
Then sighed, then wiped his eyes, then sighed, and cried,
Alas poor creature: I will soon revenge
This cruelty upon the author of it;
Henceforth this lute guilty of innocent blood,
Shall never more betray a harmless peace
To an untimely end: and in that sorrow,
As he was pashing it against a tree,
I suddenly stepped in.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Thou hast discoursed
A truth of mirth and pity.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: I reprieved
Th'intended execution with entreaties,
And interruption: but (My princely friend)
It was not strange, the music of his hand
Did overmatch birds, when his voice and beauty,
Youth, carriage and discretion, must, from men
Endued with reason, ravish admiration:
From me they did.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: But is this miracle
Not to be seen?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I won him by degrees
To choose me his companion whence he is,
Or who, as I durst modestly inquire,
So gently he would woo not to make known:
Only for reasons to himself reserved,
He told me, that some remnant of his life
Was to be spent in travail; for his fortunes,
They were nor mean, nor riotous, his friends
Not published to the world, though not obscure:
His country, Athens; and his name, Parthenophill.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: Came he with you to Cyprus?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Willingly.
The fame of our young melancholy prince,
Meleander's rare distractions, the obedience
Of young Chleophila, Thamasta's glory,
Your matchless friendship, and my desperate love
Prevailed with him, and I have lodged him privately
In Famagosta.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Now thou'rt doubly welcome:
I will not lose the sight of such a rarity
For one part of my hopes. When d'ye intend
To visit my great-spirited sister.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: May I
Without offence?

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Without offence? Parthenophill
Shall find a worthy entertainment too.
Thou art not still a coward.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: She's too excellent,
And I too low in merit.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: I'll prepare
A noble welcome. And (Friend) ere we part,
Unload to thee an overcharged heart.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: I will not court the madness of the times,
Nor fawn upon the riots that embalm
Our wanton gentry, to preserve the dust
Of their affected vanities in coffins
Of memorable shame ▪ when commonwealths
Totter and reel from that nobility
And ancient virtue, which renowns the great,
Who steer the helm of government, while mushrooms
Grow up, and make new laws to licence folly:
Why should not I, a may-game, scorn the weight
Of my sunk fortunes? snarl at the vices
which rot the land, and without fear or wit
Be mine own antic? 'tis a sport to live
When life is irksome, if we will not hug
Prosperity in others, and contemn
Affliction in ourselves. This rule is certain,
"He that pursues his safety from the school
" of state, must learn to be mad man, or fool.
Ambition, wealth, ease, I renounce the devil
That damns ye here on earth, or I will be —
Mine own mirth, or mine own tormentor, — so,
Here comes intelligence, a buz o'the court.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Rhetias, I sought thee out to tell thee news,
New, excellent new news. Cucolus, sirrah,
That gull, that young old gull, is coming this way.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: And thou art his forerunner?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Prithee hear me:
In stead of a fine guarded page,
We have got him
A boy, tricked up in neat and handsome
Fashion;
Persuaded him, that 'tis indeed a wench;
And he has entertained him, he does follow him,
Carries his sword and buckler, waits on his trencher,
Fills him his wine, tobacco, whets his knife,
Lackeys his letters, does what service else
He would employ his man in: being asked,
Why he is so irregular in courtship?
His answer is, that since great ladies use
Gentlemen ushers to go bare before them,
He knows no reason, but he may reduce
The courtiers to have women wait on them,
And he begins the fashion; he is laughed at
most complementally. Thou'lt burst to see him.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Agelastus, so surnamed for his gravity,
Was a very wise fellow, kept his countenance
All days of his life as demurely, as a judge that
Pronounceth sentence of death, on a poor rogue,
For stealing as much bacon, as would serve at a meal
With a calf's head. Yet he smiled once,
And never but once: thou art no scholar?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: I have read pamphlets dedicated to me:
Dost call him Agelastus? why did he laugh?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: To see an ass eat thistles.
Puppy, go study to be a singular coxcomb. Cuculus is an
Ordinary ape, but thou art an ape of an ape.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Thou hast a patent to abuse thy friends:
Look, look, he comes, observe him seriously.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Reach me my sword and buckler.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: They are here, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: How now (Minx) how now? Where is your duty, your distance?
Let me have service methodically tendered; you are now one of us. Your curtsy; good: remember that you are to practise courtship ▪ was thy father a piper, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: A sounder of some such wind instrument forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cucull.
sp.l: Was he so? hold up thy head; be thou musical
To me, and I will marry thee to a dancer: one
That shall ride on his foot-cloth, and maintain thee
In thy muff and hood.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: That will be fine indeed.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: That art yet but simple.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: D'ye think so?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: I have a brain; I have a head-piece;
Oh my conscience, if I take pains with thee, I should
raise thy understanding (Girl) to the height of a nurse,
Or a court-midwife at least, I will make thee big
In time, wench.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: E'en do your pleasure with me, sir.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Noble accomplished Cuculus.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Give me thy fist, innocent.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Would 'twere in thy belly, there 'tis.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: That's well, he's an honest blade, though he be blunt.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Who cares? we can be as blunt as he for's life.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Cuculus, there is within a mile or two, a sow-pig
Hath sucked a brach, and now hunts the deer, the hare,
Nay, most unnaturally the wild boar,
As well as any hound in Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Monstrous sow-pig! is't true?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: I'll be at charge of a banquet on thee for a sight of her.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Every thing takes after the dam that gave it suck:
Where hadst thou thy milk?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: I? Why, my nurse's husband was a most excellent maker
Of shuttlecocks.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: My nurse was a woman-surgeon.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: And who gave thee pap, mouse?

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: I never sucked that I remember.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: La now, a shuttlecock-maker, all thy brains are stuck with cork and feather. Cuculus, this learned courtier takes after the nurse too, a she-surgeon, which is in effect a mere matter of colours. Go, learn to paint and daub compliments, 'tis the next step to run into a new suit; my lady periwinkle here never sucked; suck thy master, and bring forth moonecalues, fop, do; this is good philosophy, sirs, make use on't.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: Bless us, what a strange creature this is?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: A gull, an arrant gull by proclamation.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Corax, the prince's chief physician;
What business speeds his haste —
Are all things well, sir?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Phew, you may wheel about, man, we know you're proud of your slovenry and practice, 'tis your virtue; the prince's melancholy fit I presume holds still.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: So do thy knavery and desperate beggary.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Aha: here's one will tickle the bandog.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: You must not go yet.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: I'll stay in spite of thy teeth. There lies my gravity:
Do what thou darest, I stand thee ▪

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Mountebank, empirics, quacksalvers, mineralists, wizards, alchimists, cast-apothecaries, old wives and barbers, are all suppositors to the right worshipful doctor, as I take it.
Some of ye are the head of your art, and the horns too, but they come by nature; thou livest single for no other end, but that thou fearest to be a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Have at thee; thou affectest railing only for thy health, thy miseries are so thick and so lasting; that thou hast not one poor denier to bestow on opening a vein. Wherefore to avoid a pleurisy, thou'lt be sure to prate thyself once a month into a whipping, and bleed in the breech in stead of the arm.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Have at thee again.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: There, there, there; oh brave doctor.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Let 'em alone.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Thou art in thy religion an atheist, in thy condition a cur, in thy diet an epicure, in thy lust a goat, in thy sleep a hog; thou takest upon thee the habit of a grave physician, but art indeed an impostrous empiric. Physicians are the bodies cobblers, rather the butchers of men's bodies; as the one patches our tattered clothes, so the other solders our diseased flesh. Come on.

sp.speaker: Cuc.
sp.p: Tot, tot, hold him tot, hold him to't, tot, tot, tot.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: The best worth in thee, is the corruption of thy mind, for that only entitles thee to the dignity of a louse: a thing bred out of the filth and superfluity of ill humours: thou bit'st anywhere ; and any man who defends not himself with the clean linen of secure honesty; him thou darest not come near. Thou art fortune's idiot, virtue's bankrupt, times dunghill, manhood's scandal, and thine own scourge. Thou wouldst hang thyself, so wretchedly miserable thou art; but that no man will trust thee with as much money as will buy a halter: and all thy stock to be sold, is not worth half as much as may procure it.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; this is flattery, gross flattery.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: I have employment for thee, and for ye all, tut, these are but good morrows between us.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Are thy bottles full?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Of rich wine, let's all suck together.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Like so many swine in a trough.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: I'll shape ye all for a device before the prince, we'll try how that can move him.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: He shall fret or laugh.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Must I make one?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Yes, and your feminine page too.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: Thanks most egregiously.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: I will not slack my part.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Wench, take my buckler.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Come all unto my chamber, the project is cast,
The time only we must attend.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: The melody must agree well, and yield sport,
When such as these are, knaves and fool's consort.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: Does this show well?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Not like a lady of the trim, new crept
Out of the shell of sluttish sweat and labour,
Into the glittering pomp of ease and wantonness,
Embroideries, and all these antic fashions,
That shape a woman monstrous; to transform
Your education, and a noble birth
Into contempt and laughter. Sister, sister,
She who derives her blood from princes, ought
To glorify her greatness by humility.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Then you conclude me proud.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Young Menaphon,
My worthy friend, has loved you long, and truly,
To witness his obedience to your scorn,
Twelve months (Wronged gentleman) he undertook
A voluntary exile. Wherefore (Sister)
In this time of his absence, have you not
Disposed of your affections on some monarch?
Or sent ambassadors to some neighbouring King
With fawning protestations of your graces?
Your rare perfections, admirable beauty?
This had been a new piece of modesty,
Would have deserved a chronicle!

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: You are bitter;
And brother, by your leave, not kindly wise.
My freedom is my births, I am not bound
To fancy your approvements, but my own.
Indeed you are an humble youth, I hear of
Your visits, and your loving commendation
To your heart's saint, Cleophila, a virgin
Of a rare excellence: what though she want
A portion to maintain a portly greatness?
Yet 'tis your gracious sweetness to descend
So low, the meekness of your pity leads ye.
She is your dear friends sister, a good soul,
An innocent.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: Thamasta.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I have given
Your Menaphon a welcome home as fits me;
For his sake entertained Parthenophill,
The handsome stranger, more familiarly
Then (I may fear) becomes me; yet for his part,
I not repent my courtesies, but you —

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: No more, no more; be affable to both:
Time may reclaim your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I pity
The youth, and trust me (Brother) love his sadness:
He talks the prettiest storeys, he delivers
His tales so gracefully, that I could sit
And listen, nay forget my meals and sleep,
To hear his neat discourses. Menaphon
Was well advised in choosing such a friend,
For pleading his true love.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Now I commend thee,
thou'lt change at last, I hope.

div.stage: Enter Menaphon and Eroclea in man's attire.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: I fear I shall.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: Have ye surveyed the garden?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Tis a curious,
A pleasantly contrived delight.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Your eye (Sir)
Hath in your travails, often met contents
Of more variety.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Not any (Lady.)

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It were impossible, since your fair presence
Makes every place where it vouchsafes to shine,
More lovely than all other helps of art
Can equal.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: What you mean by helps of art,
You know yourself best, be they as they are:
You need none I am sure to set me forth.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Twould argue want of manners, more than skill,
Not to praise praise itself.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: For your reward,
Henceforth I'll call you servant.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: Excellent sister.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Tis my first step to honour: may I fall
Lower than shame, when I neglect all service
That may confirm this favour.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Are you well, sir?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Great Princess, I am well, to see a league
Between an humble love, such as my friends is,
And a commanding virtue, such as yours is,
Are sure restoratives.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: You speak ingeniously.
Brother, he pleased to show the gallery
To this young stranger, use the time a while,
and we will altogether to the court.
I will present ye (Sir) unto the prince.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: You're all composed of fairness, and true bounty.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Come, come, we'll wait thee, sister: this beginning
Doth relish happy process.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.p: You have blessed me.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Thamasta and Kala.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Kala, oh Kala,

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: Lady.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: We are private, thou art my closet.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Lock your secrets close then:
I am not to be forced.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Never till now,
Could I be sensible of being traitor
To honour and to shame.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: You are in love.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: I am grown base — Parthenophill —

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: He's handsome,
Richly endowed; he hath a lovely face,
A winning tongue.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: If ever I must fall,
In him my greatness sinks. Love is a tyrant
Resisted; whisper in his ear, how gladly
I would steal time, to talk with him one hour;
But do it honourably; prithee Kala
Do not betray me.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Madam, I will make it
Mine own case; he shall think I am in love with him.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: I hope thou art not Kala.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: 'Tis for your sake:
I'll tell him so; but faith I am not, lady.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Pray use me kindly; let me not too soon
Be lost in my new follies. 'tis a fate
That overrules our wisdoms, whilst we strive
to live most free, we're caught in our own toils.
Diamonds cut diamonds: they who will prove
To thrive in cunning, must cure love with love.

div.head: Actus ii. scaena i.

sp.speaker: Sophronos.
sp.l: Our commonwealth is sick: 'tis more than time
That we should wake the head thereof, who sleeps
In the dull lethargy of lost security.
The commons murmur, and the nobles grieve,
The court is now turned antic, and grows wild,
Whiles all the neighbouring nations stand at gaze,
And watch fit opportunity, to wreak
Their just conceived fury, on such injuries,
As the late prince, our living master's father,
Committed against laws of truth or honour.
Intelligence comes flying in on all sides,
Whilst the unsteady multitude presume,
How that you, Aretus, and I, engross
(Out of particular ambition)
Th'affairs of government, which I for my part,
Groan under, and am weary of.

sp.speaker: Aret. Sophronos,
sp.l: I am as zealous too of shaking of
My gay state fetters, that I have bethought
Of speedy remedy; and to that end
as I have told ye, have concluded with
Corax, the prince's chief physician.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: You should have done this sooner, Aretus;
You were his tutor, and could best discern
His dispositions to inform them rightly.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: Passions of violent nature, by degrees
Are easiliest reclaimed. There's something hid
Of his distemper, which we'll now find out.
sp.stage: Enter Corax, Rhetias, Pelias, Cuculus and Grilla.
sp.l: You come on just appointment: welcome, gentlemen,
Have you won Rhetias (Corax?)

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Most sincerely.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Save ye, nobilities: do your lordships take notice of my page? 'tis a fashion of the newest edition, spick and span new, without example. Do your honour, housewife.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: There's a curtsy for you, and a curtsy for you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: 'Tis excellent: we must all follow fashion, and entertain shee-waiters.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.p: 'Twill be courtly.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: I think so; I hope the chronicles will rear me one day for a head-piece —

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Of woodcock without brains in't; barbers shall wear thee on their citherns, and hucksters set thee out in gingerbread.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Devil take thee: I say nothing to thee now; canst let me be quiet?

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: You're too perstreperous, saucebox.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Good girl, if we begin to puff once.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy tongue, the lords are in the presence.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Mum, butterfly.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: O the prince: stand and keep silence.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: O the prince: wench, thou shalt see the prince now.

div.stage: Enter Pallador, the prince, with a book in his hand.

sp.speaker: Soph. Aret.
sp.p: Sir; gracious sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Why all this company?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: A book! is this the early exercise
I did prescribe? in stead of following health,
Which all men covet, you pursue your disease.
Where's your great horse, your hounds, your set at tennis,
Your balloon ball, the practice of your dancing,
Your casting of the sledge, or learning how
To toss a pike; all changed into a sonnet?
Pray sir grant me free liberty to leave
The court, it does infect me with the sloth
Of sleep and surfeit: in the university
I have employments, which to my profession
Add profit and report: here I am lost,
And in your wilful dulness held a man
Of neither art nor honesty: you may
Command my head; pray take it, do; 'twere better
For me to lose it, than to lose my wits,
And live in bedlam: you will force me to't,
I am almost mad already.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I believe it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Letters are come from Crete, which do require
A speedy restitution of such ships,
As by your father were long since detained;
If not; defiance threatened.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: These near parts
Of Syria that adjoin, muster their friends:
And by intelligence we learn for certain,
the Syrian will pretend an ancient interest
Of tribute intermitted.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Through your land
Your subjects mutter strangely, and imagine
More than they dare speak publicly.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: And yet
They talk but oddly of you.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Hang 'em mongrels.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Of me? my subjects talk of me?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Yes, scurvily,
And think worse (Prince.)

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I'll borrow patience
A little time to listen to these wrongs,
And from the few of you which are here present,
Conceive the general voice.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: So, now he is nettled.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: By all your loves I charge ye, without fear
Or flattery, to let me know your thoughts,
And how I am interpreted: speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: For my part (Sir) I will be plain, and brief:
I think you are of nature mild and easy,
Not willingly provoked, but withal headstrong
In any passion that misleads your judgement.
I think you too indulgent to such motions,
As spring out of your own affections,
Too old to be reformed, and yet too young
To take fit council from yourself, of what
Is most amiss.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: So — tutor, your conceit?

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: I think you dote (With pardon let me speak it)
Too much upon your pleasures, and these pleasures
Are so wrapped up in self-love, that you covet
No other change of fortune: would be still
what your birth makes you, but are loath to toil
In such affairs of state as break your sleeps.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: I think you would be by the world, reputed
A man in every point complete, but are
In manners and effect indeed a child,
A boy, a very boy.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: May it please your grace,
I think you do contain within yourself
The great elixir, soul and quintessence
Of all divine perfections: are the glory
Of mankind, and the only strict example
For earthly monarchies to square out their lives by:
Times miracle, fame's pride, in knowledge, wit,
Sweetness, discourse, arms, arts —

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You are a courtier.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: But not of the ancient fashion, an't like your highness. 'tis I; I, that am the credit of the court, noble prince: and if thou wouldst by proclamation or patent, create me overseer of all the tailors in thy dominions; then, then the golden days should appear again; bread should be cheaper; fools should have more wit; knaves more honesty; and beggars more money.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: I think now —

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Peace you squall.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You have not spoken yet.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Hang him, he'll nothing but rail.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: Most abominable: out upon him.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Away Cuculus; follow the lords.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Close page, close.

div.stage: They all fall back, and steal out. Manet prince and Rhetias.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You are somewhat long a thinking.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I do not think at all.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Am I not worthy of your thought?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: My pity you are —
But not my reprehension.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Pity?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Yes, for I pity such to whom I owe service, who exchange their happiness for a misery.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Is it a misery to be a prince?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Princes who forget their sovereignty, and yield to affected passion, are weary of command. You had a father, sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Your sovereign whiles he lived. But what of him?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Nothing. I only dared to name him; that's all.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I charge thee by the duty that thou owest us, be plain in what thou meanest to speak: there's something that we must know: be free, our ears are open.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: O sir, I had rather hold a wolf by the ears, then stroke a lion, the greatest danger is the last.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: This is mere trifling — ha? are all stolen hence?
We are alone: thou hast an honest look,
Thou hast a tongue, I hope, that is not oiled
With flattery. Be open, though 'tis true,
That in my younger days I oft have heard
Agenor's name, my father, more traduced,
Than I could then observe; yet I protest,
I never had a friend, a certain friend,
That would inform me thoroughly of such errors,
As oftentimes are incident to princes.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
All this may be. I have seen a man so curious in feeling of the edge of a keen knife, that he has cut his fingers. My flesh is not of proof against the metal I
am to handle; the one is tenderer than the other.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I see then I must court thee. Take the word
Of a just prince for any thing thou speakest.
I have more than a pardon, thanks and love.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I will remember you of an old tale that something concerns you. Meleander, the great (But unfortunate statesman, was by your father treated with for a match between you and his eldest daughter, the lady Eroclea. You were both near of an age. I presume you remember a contract, and cannot forget her.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: She was a lovely beauty: prithee forward.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: To court was Eroclea brought, was courted by your father, not for prince Palador, as it followed, but to be made a prey to some less noble design. — with your favour I have forgotten the rest.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Good call it back again into thy memory,
Else losing the remainder, I am lost too.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: You charm me. In brief, a rape, by some bad agents, was attempted; by the lord Meleander her father rescue, she conveyed away Meleander accused of treason, his land seized, he himself distracted and confined to the castle where he yet lives. What had ensued was doubtful. But your father shortly after died.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: But what became of fair Eroclea?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: She never since was heard of.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: No hope lives then
Of ever, ever seeing her again.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Sir, I fear I should anger ye. There was, as I said, an old tale: I have now a new one, which may perhaps season the first with a more delightful relish.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I am prepared to hear, say what you please.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
My lord Meleander falling, on whose favour my fortunes relied, I furnished myself for travail, and
bent my course to Athens, where a pretty accident after a while came to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: My ear is open to thee.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: A young lady contracted to a noble gentleman, as the lady we last mentioned, and your highness were, being hindered by their jarring parents, stole from her home, and was conveyed like a ship-boy in a merchant, from the country where she lived, into Corinth first, and afterwards to Athens; where in much solitariness she lived like a youth almost two years, courted by all for acquaintance, but friend to none by familiarity.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: In habit of a man?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: A handsome young man, till within these three months, or less, her sweet hearty father dying some year before, or more, she had notice of it, and with much joy returned home, and as report voiced it, at Athens enjoyed her happiness: she was long an exile: for now noble sir, if you did love the lady Eroclea, why may not such safety and fate direct her, as directed the other? 'tis not impossible.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: If I did love her, Rhetias: yes I did.
Give me thy hand: as thou didst serve Meleander,
And art still true to these, henceforth serve me.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: My duty and my obedience are my surety,
But I have been too bold.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Forget the sadder story of my father,
And only Rhetias, learn to read me well,
For I must ever thank thee; thou'st unlocked
A tongue was vowed to silence, for requital
Open my bosom, Rhetias.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: What 's your meaning?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: To tie thee to an oath of secrecy —
unloose the buttons, man, thou dost it faintly,
What findst thou there?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: A picture in a tablet.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Look well upon't.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: I do — yes — let me observe it —
'Tis hers, the ladies.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Whose!

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Eroclea's.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Hers that was once Eroclea: for her sake
Have I advanced Sophronos to the helm
Of government; for her sake will restore
Meleander's honours to him; will for her sake
Beg friendship from thee, Rhetias. O be faithful,
And let no politic lord work from thy bosom
My griefs: I know thou wert put on to sift me:
But be not too secure.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I am your creature.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Continue still thy discontented fashion:
Humour the lords, as they would humour me;
I'll not live in thy debt. — we are discovered.

div.stage: Enter Amethus, Menaphon, Thamasta, Kala, Eroclea, as before.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Honour and health still wait upon the prince.
Sir, I am bold with favour to present
Unto your highness, Menaphon my friend,
Returned from travail.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: Humbly on my knees
I kiss your gracious hand.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: It is our duty
To love the virtuous.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: If my prayers or service
hold — any value, they are vowed yours ever.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I have a fist for thee too (Stripling) thou'rt started up prettily since I saw thee. Hast learned any wit abroad? Canst tell news, and swear lies with a grace like a true traveller? What new ouzel's this?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Your highness shall do right to your own judgement,
In taking more than common notice of
This stranger, an Athenian, named Parthenophill.
One, (Whom if mine opinion do not soothe me
Too grossly) for the fashion of his mind,
Deserves a dear respect.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Your commendations,
Sweet cousin, speaks him nobly.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: All the powers
That centinel just thrones, double these guards
About your sacred excellence.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What fortune led him to Cyprus!

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My persuasions won him.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: And if your highness please to hear the entrance
Into their first acquaintance, you will say —

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: It was the newest, sweetest, prettiest accident,
That ere delighted your attention.
I can discourse it, sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Some other time.
How is a called?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Parthenophill.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Parthenophill?
We shall sort time to take more notice of him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: His wonted melancholy still pursues him.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: I told you so.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: You must not wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: I do not, lady.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: Shall we to the castle?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: We will attend ye both.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: All three — I'll go too. Hark in thine ear, gallant: I'll keep the old mad man in chat, whilst thou gabblest to the girl: my thumb's upon my lips, not a word.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: I need not fear thee, Rhetias. — sister, soon
Expect us: this day we will range the city.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Well, soon I shall expect ye. — Kala?

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: Trust me.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Troop on — love, love, what a wonder thou art?

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: May I not be offensive, sir?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Your pleasure; yet pray be brief.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Then briefly, good, resolve me:
Have you a mistress, or a wife?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I have neither.

sp.speaker: Kala
sp.l: Nor did you ever love in earnest any
Fair lady, whom you wished to make your own?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Not any truly.

sp.speaker: Kala
sp.l: What your friends or means are
I will not be inquisitive to know,
Nor do I care to hope for. But admit
A dowry were thrown down before your choice,
Of beauty, noble birth, and sincere affection,
How gladly would you entertain it? (Young man)
I do not tempt you idly.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I shall thank you,
When my unsettled thoughts can make me sensible
Of what 'tis to be happy: for the present
I am your debtor: and fair gentlewoman,
Pray give me leave as yet to study ignorance,
for my weak brains conceive not what concern me.
— another time. —

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Do I break off your parley
That you are parting? Sure my woman loves you.
Can she speak well, Parthenophill?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Yes, madam:
Discreetly chaste she can: she hath much won
On my belief, and in few words, but pithy,
Much moved my thankfulness. You are her lady,
Your goodness aims (I know) at her preferment:
Therefore I may be bold to make confession
Of truth, if ever I desire to thrive
In woman's favour. Kala is the first
Whom my ambition shall bend to.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Indeed.
But say a nobler love should interpose?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Where real worth, and constancy first settle
A hearty truth, there greatness cannot shake it,
Nor shall it mine: yet I am but an infant
In that construction, which must give clear light
To Kala's merit: riper hours hereafter
Must learn me how to grow rich in deserts.
Madam, my duty waits on you.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Come hither.
If ever henceforth I desire to thrive
In woman's favours, Kala is the first
Whom my ambition shall bend to — 'twas so.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.l: These very words he spoke.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: These very words
Curse thee, unfaithful creature, to thy grave:
Thou wouldst him for thyself?

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: You said I should.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: My name was never mentioned!

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Madam, no:
We were not come to that.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Not come to that?
Art thou a rival fit to cross my fate?
Now poverty and a dishonest fame,
The waiting-woman's wages, be thy payment.
False, faithless, wanton beast, I'll spoil your carriage;
There's not a page, a groom, nay, not a citizen
That shall be cast upon ye. Kala,
I'll keep thee in my service all thy life time,
Without hope of a husband or a suitor.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: I have not verily deserved this cruelty.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Parthenophill shall know, if he respect
My birth, the danger of a fond neglect.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Are you so quick? Well, I may chance to cross
Your peevishness. Now though I never meant
The young man for myself; yet if he love me,
I'll have him, or I'll run away with him,
And let her do her worst then: what, we are all
But flesh and blood; the same thing that will do
My lady good, will please her woman too.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Tread softly (Trollio) my father sleeps still.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: I forsooth: but he sleeps like a hare with his eyes open and that's no good sign.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sure thou art weary of this sullen living,
But I am not; for I take more content
In my obedience here, than all delights
The time presents elsewhere.
Menander within. Oh!

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Dost hear that groan?

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: Hear it? I shudder, it was a strong blast, young mistress, able to root up heart, liver, lungs and all.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: My much-wronged father: let me view his face.

div.stage: Draws the arras, Meleander discovered in a chair sleeping.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: Lady mistress, shall I fetch a Barbour to steal away his rough beard, whiles he sleeps in's naps? He never looks in a glass, and 'tis high time on conscience for him to be trimmed, has not been under the shaver's hand almost these four years.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Peace, fool.

sp.speaker: Trol.
sp.p: I could clip the old ruffian, there's hair enough to stuff all the great codpieces in Switzerland. 'a begins to stir, 'a stirs. Bless us how his eyes roll. A good year keep your lordship in your right wits, I beseech ye.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Cleophila?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Sir, I am here, how d'ye sir?

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: Sir, is your stomach up yet? get some warm porridge in your belly, 'tis a very good settle-brain.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The raven croaked, and hollow shrieks of owls
Sung dirges at her funeral; I laughed
The whiles: for 'twas no boot to weep. The girl
Was fresh and full of youth: but, oh the cunning
Of tyrants that look big, their very frowns
Doom poor souls guilty, ere their cause be heard.
Good. What art thou, and thou?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am Cleophila,
Your woeful daughter.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.l: I am Trollia your honest implement.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I know ye both. Alas, why d'ye use me thus!
Thy sister, my Eroclea, was so gentle,
That turtles in their down do feed more gall,
Than her spleen mixed with: yet when winds and storm
Drive dirt and dust on banks of spotless snow,
The purest whiteness is no such defence
Against the sullying foulness of that fury.
So raved Agenor, that great man, mischief
Against the girl — 'twas a politic trick,
We were too old in honour. — I am lean
And fallen away extremely; most assuredly
I have not dined these three days.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Will you now, sir?

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: I beseech ye heartily sir. I feel a horrible puking myself.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Am I stark mad?

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: No, no, you are but a little staring — there's difference between staring and stark mad. You are but whimsied, yet crotcheted, conumndrummed, or so.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Here's all my care: and I do often sigh
For thee, Cleophyla: we are secluded
From all good people. But take heed, Amethus
Was son to Doryla, Agenor's sister.
There's some ill blood about him, if the surgeon
Have not been very skilful to let all out.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am (Alas) too grieved to think of love,
That must concern me least.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Sirrah, be wise, be wise.

div.stage: Enter Amethus, Menaphon, Eroclea (As before) and Rhetias.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: Who I? I will be monstrous and wise immediately. Welcome, gentlemen, the more the merrier, I'll lay the cloth, and set the stools in a readiness, for I see here is some hope of dinner now.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: My lord Meleander, Menaphon your kinsman
Newly returned from travail, comes to tender
His duty t'ee: to you his love, fair mistress.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I would I could as easily remove
Sadness from your remembrance, sir, as study
To do you faithful service — my dear cousin,
All best of comforts bless your sweet obedience.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: One chief of 'em (Worthy cousin) lives
In you, and your well-doing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: This young stranger
Will well deserve your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: For my friend's sake,
Lady pray give him welcome.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: He has met it, if sorrows can look kindly.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: You much honour me.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: How 'a turns the company: sure my passion will betray my weakness — oh my master, my noble master, do not forget me, I am still the humblest, and the most faithful in heart of those that serve you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: There's wormwood in that laughter, 'tis the usher to a violent extremity.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I am a weak old man. All these are come to jeer my ripe calamities.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.p: Good uncle!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But I'll outstare thou all, fools, desperate fools,
You are cheated, grossly cheated, range, range on,
And roll about the world to gather moss,
The moss of honour, gay reports, gay clothes,
Gay wives, huge empty buildings, whose proud roofs,
Shall with their pinnacles, even reach the stars.
Ye work and work like moles, blind in the paths,
That are bored through the crannies of the earth,
To charge your hungry souls with such full surfeits,
as being gorged once, make thou lean with plenty.
And when ye have skimmed the vomit of your riots,
You're fat in no felicity but folly,
Than your last sleeps seize on 'ee. Then the troops
Of worms crawl round, and, feast, good cheer, rich fare,
Dainty delicious — here's Chleophyla:
All the poor stock of my remaining thrift;
You, you, the prince's cousin: how d'ye like her?
(Amethus) how d'ye like her?

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: My intents are just and honourable.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Sir, believe him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Take her. — we two must part, go to him, do.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: This sight is full of horror.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: This is sense yet in this distraction.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: In this jewel I have given away,
All what I can call mine. When I am dead,
Save charge; let me be buried in a nook.
No guns, no pompous whining: these are fooleries.
If whiles we live, we stalk about the streets,
Justled by carmen, foot-posts, and fine apes,
In silken coats, unminded, and scarce thought on;
It is not comely to be haled to the earth,
Like high fed jades upon a tilting-day,
In antique trappings: scorn to useless tears.
Eroclea was not coffined so: she perished,
And no eye dropped save mine, and I am childish.
I talk like one that dotes; laugh at me, Rhetias,
Or rail at me: they will not give me meat:
They have starved me: but I'll henceforth be mine own cook.
Good morrow: 'tis too early for my cares
To revel. I will break my heart a little,
And tell ye more hereafter. Pray be merry.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: I'll follow him. My lord Amethus, use your time
Respectively. Few words to purpose soonest prevail:
Study no long orations; be plain and short,
I'll follow him.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Cleophyla, although these blacker clouds
Of sadness, thicken and make dark the sky
Of thy fair eyes, yet give me leave to follow
The stream of my affections: they are pure,
Without all mixture of unnoble thoughts.
Can you be ever mine?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am so low
In mine own fortunes, and my father woes,
That I want words to tell ye, you deserve
A worthier choice.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: But give me leave to hope.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My friend is serious.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sir, this for answer: if I ever thrive
In an earthly happiness, the next
To my good fathers wisht recovery,
Must be my thankfulness to your great merit;
Which I dare promise for the present time:
You cannot urge more from me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Ho, Cleophyla?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: This gentleman is moved.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Your eyes, Parthenophill,
Are guilty of some passion.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Friend, what ails thee?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: All is not well within me, sir.
Meleander within. Cleophyla?

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: Sweet maid, forget me not; we now must part.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Still you shall have my prayer.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: Still you my truth.

div.head: Actus iii. Scaena i.
div.stage: Enter Cuculus and Grilla, Cuculus in a black velvet cap, and a white feather, with a paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: Cuculus.
sp.p: Do not I look freshly, and like a youth of the trim?

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: As rare an old youth as ever walked cross-gartered.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Here are my mistresses mustered in white and black. Kala the waiting-woman. I will first begin at the soot: stand thou for Kala.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: I stand for Kala, do your best and your worst.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: I must look big, and care little or nothing for her, because she is a creature that stands at livery. Thus I talk wisely, and to no purpose. Wench, as it is not fit that thou shouldst be either fair or honest; so considering thy service, thou art as thou art, and so are thy betters, let them be what they can be. Thus in despite and defiance of all thy good parts, if I cannot endure thy baseness, 'tis more out of thy courtesy, than my deserving, and so I expect thy answer.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: I must confess —

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: You are —

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: That's true too.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: To speak you right, a very scurvy fellow. —

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Away, away, dost think so?

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: A very foul-mouthed, and misshapen coxcomb

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: I'll never believe it by this hand.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.l: A maggot, most unworthy to creep in —
— to the least wrinkle of a gentlewoman's
(What d'ye call) good conceit, or so, or what
You will else. — were you not refined by courtship
And education, which in my blear eyes
Makes you appear as sweet as any nosegay,
Or savoury cod of musk new fallen from th'cat.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: This shall serve well enough for the waiting-woman. My next mistress is Cleophyla, the old madman's daughter: I must come to her in whining tune, sigh, wipe mine eyes, fold my arms, and blubber out my speech as thus: even as a kennel of hounds (Sweet lady) cannot catch a hare, when they are full paunched on the carrion of a dead horse: so, even so the gorge of my affections being full crammed with the garboils of your condolements, doth tickle me with the prick (As it were) about me, and fellow-feeling of howling outright.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: This will do't, if we will hear.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Thou seest I am crying ripe, I am such another tender-hearted fool.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: Even as the snuff of a candle that is burned in the socket, goes out, and leaves a strong perfume behind it; or as a piece of toasted cheese next the heart in a morning is a restorative for a sweet breath: so, even so the odoriferous savour of your love doth perfume my heart, (Hay ho) with the pure scent of an intolerable content, and not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
By this hand 'tis excellent. Have at thee last of all: for the Princess Thamasta, she that is my mistress
indeed, she is abominably proud. A lady of a damnable, high, turbulent, and generous spirit. But I have a loud-mouthed cannon of mine own to batter her, and a penned speech of purpose observe it.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: Thus I walk by, hear and mind you not.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: Though haughty as the devil or his dam,
Thou dost appear, great mistress: yet I am
Like to an ugly firework, and can mount
Above the region of thy sweet ac — count.
Wert thou the moon herself, yet having seen thee,
Behold the man ordained to move within thee.
— look to yourself, housewife; answer me
In strong lines you're best.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.l: Keep off, poor fool, my beams will strike thee blind:
Else if thou touch me, touch me but behind.
In palaces, such as pass in before,
Must be great princes; for at the back door
Tatterdemalions wait, who know not how
To get admittance: such a one — art thou.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, this is downright roaring.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: I know how to present a big lady in her own cue. But pray in earnest, are you in love with all these?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Pish, I have not a rag of love about me. 'tis only a foolish humour I am possessed with, to be surnamed the conqueror. I will court any thing; be in love with nothing, nor no — thing.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: A rare man you are, I protest.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Yes, I know I am a rare man, and I ever held myself so.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: In amorous contemplation on my life;
Courting his page by hell. con.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: A gross untruth; I'll justify it, sir, at any time, place, weapon.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Marry shall she.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: No quarrels, goody whisk. Lay by your trumperies, and fall to your practice. Instructions are ready for you all. Pelias is your leader, follow him. Get credit now or never. Vanish, Doodles, vanish.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: For the device.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: The same, get 'ee gone, and make no bawling.
sp.l: To waste my time thus drone-like in the court,
And lose so many hours, as my studies
Have hoarded up, is to be like a man
That creeps both on his hands and knees, to climb
A mountain's top, where when he is ascended,
One careless slip down, tumbles him again
Into the bottom whence a first began.
I need no prince's favour: princes need
My art. Then Corax, be no more a gull,
The best of 'em cannot fool thee, nay, they shall not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: We find him timely now let's learn the cause.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: 'Tis fit we should — sir, we approve you learned,
And since your skill can best discern the humours
That are predominant, in bodies subject
To alteration: tell us (Pray) what devil
This melancholy is, which can transform
Men into monsters.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: You're yourself a scholar,
And quick of apprehension: melancholy
Is not as you conceive. Indisposition
of body, but the mind's disease. So ecstasy,
Fantastic dotage, madness, frenzy, rupture,
Of mere imagination differ partly
vid. Democrit. Junior. from melancholy, which is briefly this,
A mere commotion of the mind, o'ercharged
With fear and sorrow; first begotten i'th' brain,
The seat of reason, and from thence derived
As suddenly into the heart, the seat
Of our affection.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: There are sundry kinds
Of this disturbance.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Infinite, it were
More easy to conjecture every hour
We have to live, then reckon up the kinds,
Or causes of this anguish of the mind.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Thus you conclude, that as the cause is doubtful,
The cure must be impossible; and then
Our prince (Poor gentleman) is lost for ever,
As well unto himself, as to his subjects.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: My lord, you are too quick; thus much I dare
Promise, and do, ere many minutes pass,
I will discover whence his sadness is,
Or undergo the censure of my ignorance.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.p: You are a noble scholar.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: For reward,
You shall make your own demand.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: May I be sure?

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.p: We both will pledge our truth.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: 'Tis soon performed,
That I may be discharged from my attendance
At court, and never more be sent for after:
Or if I be, may rats gnaw all my books,
If I get home once, and come here again,
though my neck stretch a halter for't, I care not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Come, come, you shall not fear it.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: I'll acquaint ye
With what is to be done, and you shall fashion it.

div.stage: Enter Kala and Eroclea, as before.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: My lady does expect 'ee, thinks all time
Too slow till you come to her: wherefore young man,
If you intend to love me, and me only,
Before we part, without more circumstance
Let us betrothe ourselves.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: I dare not wrong thou;
You are too violent.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Wrong me no more
Than I wrong you: be mine, and I am yours:
I cannot stand on points.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Then to resolve
All further hopes, you never can be mine,
Must not, (And pardon though I say) you shall not.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: The thing is sure a gelding — shall not? well,
You're best to prate unto my lady now,
What proffer I have made.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Never, I vow.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Do, do, 'tis but a kind heart of mine own,
And ill luck can undo me. — be refused?
O scurvy. — pray walk on, I'll overtake 'ee.
What a greene-sickness-livered boy is this!
My maidenhead will shortly grow so stale,
That 'twill be mouldy: but I'll mar her market.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Parthenophill passed the way; prithee Kala
direct me to him.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Yes, I can direct 'ee:
But you (Sir) must forbear.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Forbear!

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: I said so.
Your bounty has engaged my truth; receive
A secret, that will, as you are a man,
Startle your reason: 'tis but mere respect
Of what I owe to thankfulness. (Dear sir)
The stranger whom your courtesy received
For friend, is made your rival.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Rival, Kala.
Take heed, thou art too credulous.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: My lady
Dotes on him: I will place you in a room,
Where, though you cannot hear, yet you shall see
Such passages as will confirm the truth
Of my intelligence.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: 'Twill make me mad.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Yes, yes: it makes me mad too, that a gentleman
So excellently sweet, so liberal,
So kind, so proper, should be so betrayed
By a young smooth-chinned straggler: but for love's sake
Bear all with manly courage. — not a word,
I am undone then.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: That were too much pity:
Honest most honest Kala; 'tis thy care,
Thy serviceable care.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: You have even spoken all can be said or thought.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I will reward thee:
But as for him, ungentle boy, I'll whip
His falsehood with a vengeance. —

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: O speak little.
Walk up these stairs, and take this key, it opens
A chamber door, where at that window yonder,
You may see all their courtship.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I am silent.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: As little noise as may be, I beseech ye;
There is a back-stair to convey ye forth
Unseen or unsuspected. — he that cheats
A waiting-woman of a free good turn
She longs for, must expect a shrewd revenge.
Sheep-spirited boy, although he had not married me,
He might have proffered kindness in a corner,
And ne'er have been the worse for't. They are come;
On goes my set of faces most demurely.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Forbear the room.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Whosoever requires access to me, deny him entrance till I call thee, and wait without.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: I shall. Sweet Venus, turn his courage to a snowball, I heartily beseech it.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I expose
The honour of my birth, my fame, my youth,
To hazard of much hard construction,
In seeking an adventure of a parley
So private with a stranger; if your thoughts
Censure me not with mercy, you may soon
Conceive, I have laid by that modesty,
Which should preserve a virtuous name unstained.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Lady, to shorten long excuses; time
And safe experience have so thoroughly armed
My apprehension, with a real taste
Of your most noble nature, that to question
The least part of your bounties, or that freedom
which heaven hath with a plenty made you rich in,
Would argue me uncivil, which is more,
Base-bred, and which is most of all, unthankful.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: The constant loadstone, and the steel are found
In several mines: yet is there such a league
Between these minerals, as if one vein
Of earth had nourished both. The gentle myrtle
Is not ingraft upon an olives's stock:
Yet nature hath between them locked a secret
Of sympathy, that being planted near,
They will both in their branches, and their roots
Embrace each other; twines of ivy round
The well grown oak; the vine doth court the elm;
Yet these are different plants. Parthenophill,
Consider this aright, than these sleight creatures,
Will fortify the reasons I should frame
For that ungrounded (As thou think'st) affection,
Which is submitted to a stranger's pity.
True love may blush, when shame repents too late,
But in all actions nature yields to fate.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Great lady, 'twere a dulness must exceed
The grossest and most sottish kind of ignorance,
Not to be sensible of your intents:
I clearly understand them. Yet so much
The difference between that height and lowness,
Which doth distinguish our unequal fortunes,
Dissuades me from ambition; that I am
Humbler in my desires, then loves own power
Can any way raise up.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I am a Princess,
And know no law of slavery, to sue,
Yet be denied?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I am so much a subject
to every law of noble honesty,
That to transgress the vows of perfect friendship,
I hold a sacrilege as foul, and cursed,
As if some holy temple had been robbed,
And I the thief.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Thou art unwise, young man,
To enrage a lioness.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: It were unjust
To falsify a faith, and ever after
Disrobed of that fair ornament, live naked,
A scorn to time and truth.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Remember well who I am, and what thou art.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: That remembrance
Prompts me to worthy duty, oh great lady.
If some few days have tempted your free heart,
To cast away affection on a stranger:
If that affection have so overswayed
Your judgement, that it in a manner hath
Declined your sovereignty of birth and spirit:
How can ye turn your eyes off from that glass,
Wherein you may new trim, and settle right
A memorable name?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: The youth is idle.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Days, months and years are past, since Menaphon
Hath loved and served you truly: Menaphon;
A man of no large distance in his blood,
From yours; in qualities desertful, graced
With youth, experience; every happy gift
That can by nature, or by education
Improve a gentleman: for him (Great lady)
Let me prevail, that you will yet at last,
Unlock the bounty, which your love and care
Have wisely treasured up, t'enrich his life.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Thou hast a moving eloquence; Parthenophill,
Parthenophill, in vain we strive to cross
The destiny that guides us. My great heart
Is stooped so much beneath that wonted pride
That first disguised it, that I now prefer
A miserable life with thee, before
All other earthly comforts.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Menaphon, by me, repeats the selfsame words to you:
You are too cruel, if you can distrust
His truth, or my report.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Go where thou wilt,
I'll be an exile with thee, I will learn
To bear all change of fortunes.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: For my friend, I plead with grounds of reason.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: For thy love,
Hard-hearted youth, I here renounce all thoughts
Of other hopes, of other entertainments, —

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Stay, as you honour virtue.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: When the proffers of other greatness —

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Lady.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: When entreats of friends; —

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: I'll ease your grief.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Respect of kindred;

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Pray give me hearing.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Loss of fame;

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: I crave but some few minutes.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Shall infringe my vows, let heaven —

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: My love speak t'ee; hear then, go on.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Thy love, why 'tis a charm to stop a vow
In its most violent course.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Cupid has broke
His arrows here; and like a child unarmed,
Comes to make sport between us with no weapon,
but feathers stolen from his mother's doves.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: This is mere trifling.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Lady, take a secret.
I am as you are, in a lower rank
Else of the self same sex, a maid, a virgin.
And now to use your own words, if your thoughts
Censure me not with mercy, you may soon
Conceive, I have laid by that modesty,
Which should preserve a virtuous name unstained.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Are you not mankind then?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: When you shall read
The story of my sorrows, with the change
Of my misfortunes, in a letter printed
From my unforged relation; I believe
You will not think the shedding of one tear,
A prodigality that misbecomes
Your pity and my fortune.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Pray conceal the errors of my passions.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Would I had
Much more of honour (As for life I value't not)
To venture on your secrecy.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: It will be
A hard task for my reason, to relinquish
The affection which was once devoted thine,
I shall a while repute thee still the youth
I loved so dear.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: You shall find me ever, your ready faithful servant.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: O the powers
Who do direct our hearts, laugh at our follies!
We must not part yet.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Let not my unworthiness alter your good opinion.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I shall henceforth
Be jealous of thy company with any;
my fears are strong and many.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: Did your ladyship call me?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.p: Your servant Menaphon desires admittance.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: With your leave, great mistress! I come —
So private: is this well, Parthenophill?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Sir, noble sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You are unkind and treacherous.
This 'tis to trust a straggler.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Prithee servant.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I dare not question you, you are my mistress;
My prince's nearest kinswoman, but he —

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Come, you are angry.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: Henceforth I will bury
Unmanly passion in perpetual silence.
I'll court mine own distraction, dote on folly,
Creep to the mirth and madness of the age,
Rather than be so slaved again to woman,
Which in her best of constancy is steddist
In change and scorn.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: How dare ye talk to me thus?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Dare? Were you not own sister to my friend,
Sister to my Amethus; I would hurl ye
As far off from mine eyes, as from my heart;
For I would never more look on ye. Take
Your jewel t'ee. And youth, keep under wing,
Or — boy — boy.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: If commands be of no force,
Let me entreat thee, Menaphon.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Tis naught, fie, fie, Parthenophill, have I deserved
To be thus used?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: I do protest —

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You shall not,
Henceforth I will be free, and hate my bondage.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Away, away to court, the prince is pleased
To see a mask tonight , we must attend him:
'Tis near upon the time. — how thrives your suit?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: The judge, your sister, will decide it shortly.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Parthenophill, I will not trust you from me.

div.stage: Enter prince, Aretas, Corax (With a paper-plot) servants with torches.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Lights and attendance, I will show your highness,
A trifle of mine own brain if you can,
Imagine you were now in the university,
You'll take it well enough, a scholar's fancy,
A quab. 'tis nothing else a very quab.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: We will observe it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes, and grace it too sir.
For Corax else is humerous and testy.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: By any means, men singular in art,
Have always some odd whimsy more than usual.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: The name of this conceit.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Sir, it is called the mask of melancholy.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.p: We must look for nothing but sadness, here then.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Madness rather
In several changes: melancholy is
The root as well of every apish frenzy,
Laughter and mirth, as dulness. Pray my lord
Hold and observe the plot, 'tis there expressed
In kind, what shall be now expressed in action.
No interpretation, take your places quickly.
Nay, nay, leave ceremony: sound to the entrance.

div.stage: Enter Rhetias, his face whited, black shag hair, long nails, a piece of raw meat.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Bow, bow, wow, wow; the moon's eclipsed, I'll to the churchyard and sup: since I turned wolf, I bark and howl, and dig up graves, I will never have the sun shine again, 'tis midnight, deep dark midnight, get a prey, and fall too, I have caught thee now. Are.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: This kind is called, lycanthropia, sir,
When men conceive themselves wolves.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Here I find it.

div.stage: Enter Pelias. A crown of feathers on, antically rich.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: I will hang 'em all, and burn my wife: was I not an emperor; my hand was kissed, and ladies lay down before me. In triumph did I ride with my nobles about me, till the mad-dog bit me, I fell, and I fell, and I fell. It shall be treason by statute for any man to name water, or wash his hands throughout all my dominions; break all the looking-glasses, I will not see my horns; my wife cuckolds me, she is a whore, a whore, a whore, a whore.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Hydrophobia term you this?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: And men possessed so, shun all sight of water:
Sometimes, if mixed with jealousy, it renders them.
Incurable, and oftentimes brings death.

div.stage: Enter philosopher in black rags, a copper chain on, an old gown half off, and book.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Philosophers dwell in the moon speculation and theory girdle the world about like a wall. Ignorance like an atheist, must be damned in the pit. I am very, very poor, and poverty is the physic for the soul: my opinions are pure and perfect. Envy is a monster, and I defy the beast.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Delirium this is called, which is mere dotage,
Sprung from ambition first, and singularity,
Self love, and blind opinion of true merit.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I not dislike the course.

div.stage: Enter Grilla in a rich gown, great vardingale, great ruff, muss, fan, and coxcomb on her head.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, and no forsooth, is not this fine, I pray, your blessing gaffer, here, here, here did he give me a shove, and cut off's tail: buss, buss nuncle, and there's a pum for daddy.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: You find this noted there, phrenitis.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Pride is the ground on't;
It reigns most in women.

div.stage: Enter Cuculus like a bedlam singing.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: They that will learn to drink a health in hell,
Must learn on earth to take tobacco well,
To take tobacco well, to take tobacco well:
For in hell they drink nor wine, nor ale, nor beer,
But fire, and smoke, and stench, as we do here.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I'll soup thee up.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Thou'st straight to execution.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: Fool, fool, fool, catch me and thou canst.

sp.speaker: Philos.
sp.p: Expel him the house, 'tis a dunce.

div.l: Hark, did ye not hear a rumbling,
The gobblings are now a tumbling:
I'll tear 'em, I'll sear 'em,
I'll roar 'em, I'll gore 'em:
Now, now, now, my brains are a jumbling, —

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You name this here, hypochondriacal.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Which is a windy flatuous humour stuffing
