The head, and thence derived to th'animal parts
To be too overcurious, loss of goods,
Or friends, excess of fear, or sorrow's cause it.

div.stage: Enter a sea-nimph big-bellied, singing and dancing.
div.l: Good your honours,
Pray your worships,
Dear your beauties,

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: Hang thee.
To lash your sides,
To tame your hides,
To scourge your pride's,
And bang thee.

sp.speaker: Nymph
sp.l: Were pretty and dainty, and I will begin,
See how they do jeer me, deride me, and grin:
Come sport me, come court me, your topsail advance,
And let us conclude our delights in a dance.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A dance, a dance, a dance.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: This is the wanton melancholy; women
With child possessed with this strange fury often,
Have danced three days together without ceasing.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: 'Tis very strange: but heaven is full of miracles.

div.stage: Which ended, they all run out in couples.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: We are thy debtor (Corax) for the gift
Of this invention: but the plot deceives us;
What means this empty space.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: One kind of melancholy
Is only left untouched; 'twas not in art
To personate the shadow of that fancy.
'Tis named love-melancholy. As for instance,
Admit this stranger here (Young man, stand forth)
Entangled by the beauty of this lady,
The great Thamasta, cherished in his heart
The weight of hopes and fears: it were impossible,
To limn his passions in such lively colours,
As his own proper sufferance could express.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: You are not modest sir.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Am I your mirth?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Love is the tyrant of the heart, it darkens
Reason, confounds discretion, deaf to counsel:
It runs a headlong course to desperate madness.
O were your highness but touched home, and thoroughly,
With this (What shall I call it) devil —

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Hold, let no man henceforth name the word again
Wait you my pleasure, youth; 'tis late, to rest.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: My lords —

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Enough, thou art a perfect artsman.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Panther's may hide their heads, not change the skin:
And love pent never so close yet will be seen.

div.head: Actus iv. Scaena i.

sp.speaker: Amethus.
sp.p: Dote on a stranger?

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.p: Court him, plead, and sue to him,

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: Affectionately?

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.p: Servilely; and pardon me, if I say basely.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Women in their passions,
Like false fierce flash, to fright our trembling senses;
Yet in themselves contain nor light nor heat.
My sister do this? She, whose pride did scorn
All thoughts that were not busied on a crown?
To fall so far beneath her fortunes now?
You are my friend.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.p: What I confirm, is truth.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: Truth, Menaphon?

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: If I conceived you were
Jealous of my sincerity and plainness,
Than sir —

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: What then, sir?

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: I would then resolve,
You were as changeable in vows of friendship,
As is Thamasta in her choice of love.
That sin is double, running in a blood,
Which justifies another being worse.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: My Menaphon, excuse me, I grow wild,
And would not willingly believe the truth
Of my dishonour: she shall know how much
I am a debtor to thy noble goodness,
By checking the contempt, her poor desires
Have sunk her fame in. Prithee tell me (Friend)
How did the youth receive her?

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: With a coldness,
As modest and as hopeless, as the trust
I did repose in him, could wish, or merit.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: I will esteem him dear.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Sir, your sister.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Servant, I have employment for ye.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Hark ye:
The mask of your ambition is fallen off,
Your pride hath stooped to such an abject lowness,
That you have now discovered to report
Your nakedness in virtue, honours, shame —

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: You are turned satire.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: All the flatteries
Of greatness have exposed ye to contempt.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: This is mere railing.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: You have sold your birth, for lust.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: Lust?

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Yes, and at a dear expense
Purchased the only glories of a wanton.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: A wanton?

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Let repentance stop your mouth.
Learn to redeem your fault.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: I hope your tongue has not betrayed my honesty.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: If (Menaphon,) I hitherto have striven;
To keep a wary guard about my fame;
If I have used a woman's skill to sift
the constancy of your protested love;
You cannot in the justice of your judgement,
Impute that to a coyness, or neglect,
Which my discretion and your service aimed
For noble purposes.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: Great mistress, no:
I rather quarrel with mine own ambition,
That durst to soar so high, as to feed hope
Of any least desert, that might entitle
My duty, to a pension from your favours.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: And therefore lady (Pray observe him well)
He henceforth covets plain equality;
Endeavouring to rank his fortunes low,
With some fit partner, whom without presumption,
Without offence, or danger, he may cherish;
Yes and command too, as a wife; a wife;
A wife, my most great lady

sp.speaker: Kala
sp.p: All will out.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Now I perceive the league of amity,
Which you have long between ye, vowed and kept,
Is sacred and inviolable, secrets
Of every nature are in common t'ee:
I have trespassed, and I have been faulty:
Let not too rude a censure doom me guilty,
Or judge my error wilful without pardon.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Gracious and virtuous mistress.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: 'Tis a trick,
There is no trust in female cunning (Friend)
Let her first purge her follies past, and clear
The wrongs done to her honour, by some sure
Apparent testimony of her constancy:
Or we will not believe these childish plots;
As you respect my friendship, lend no ear
to a reply. Think on't.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray love your fame.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Gone! I am sure awaked. Kala I find,
You have not been so trusty as the duty
You owed, required.

sp.speaker: Kala
sp.p: Not I? I do protest, I have been, madam.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Be no matter what.
I'm paid in mine own coin; something I must,
And speedily — so, — seek out Cuculus
Bid him attend me instantly.

sp.speaker: Kala
sp.l: That antic!
The trim old youth shall wait ye.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Wounds may be mortal, which are wounds indeed:
"But no wounds deadly, till our honours bleed. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Thar't an excellent fellow. Diabolo. O this lousy close-stool empirics, that will undertake all cures, yet know not the causes of any disease. Dog-leaches. By the four elements I honour thee, could find in my heart to turn knave, and be thy flatterer.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Sirrah, 'tis pity thou'st not been a scholar;
Thou'rt honest, blunt, and rude enough. O conscience!
But for thy lord now, I have put him to't.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: He chafes hugely, fumes like a stew-pot; is he not monstrously overgone in frenzy?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Rhetias, 'tis not a madness, but his sorrow's
Close griping grief, and anguish of the soul
That torture him: he carries hell on earth
Within his bosom, 'twas a prince's tyranny
Caused his distraction, and a prince's sweetness
Must qualify that tempest of his mind.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Corax, to praise thy art, were to assure
The misbelieving world, that the sun shines,
when 'tis in th'full meridian of his beauty.
No cloud of black detraction can eclipse
The light of thy rare knowledge; henceforth casting
All poor disguises off, that play in rudeness,
Call me your servant: only for the present,
I wish a happy blessing to your labours;
Heaven crown your undertakings; and believe me,
Ere many hours can pass, at our next meeting,
The bonds my duty owes, shall be full cancelled.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Farewell — a shrewd-brain whoreson, there's pith
In his untoward plainness. —
sp.stage: Enter Trollio with a murrain on.
sp.l: Now, the news!

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: Worshipful master doctor, I have a great deal of I cannot tell what, to say t'ee; my lord thunders: every word that comes out of his mouth, roars like a cannon: the house shook once, my young lady dares not be seen.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: We will roar with him, Trollio, if he roar.

sp.speaker: Trol.
sp.p: He has got a great pole-axe in his hand, and fences it up and down the house, as if he were to make room for the pageants. I have provided me a murrain for fear of a clap on the coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: No matter for the murrain, here's my cap:
Thus I will pull it down; and thus outstare him.

sp.speaker: Trol.
sp.l: The physician is got as mad as my lord. —
Oh brave, a man of worship.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Let him come, Trollio, I will firk his trangdido,
And bounce, and bounce in metal, honest Trollio.

sp.speaker: Trol.
sp.p: He vapours like a tinker, and struts like a juggler.

div.stage: Menander within. So ho ▪ so ho.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: There, there, there; look to your right worshipful, look to yourself.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Show me the dog, whose triple throated noise,
Hath roused a lion from his uncouth den,
To tear the cur in pieces.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Stay thy paws,
Courageous beast, else lo, the gorgeous skull,
That shall transform thee, to that restless stone,
Which Sisyphus rolls up against the hill;
Whence tumbling down again, it, with his weight
Shall crush thy bones, and puff thee into air.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Hold, hold thy conquering breath, 'tis stronger far
Than gunpowder and garlic. If the fates
Have spun my thread, and my spent-clue of life
Be now untwisted, let us part like friends.
Lay up my weapon, Trollio, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Trol.
sp.p: Yes sir, with all my heart. —

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: This friend and I will walk, and gabble wisely.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I allow the motion: on.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: So politicians thrive,
That with their crabbed faces, and sly tricks
Legerdemain, ducks, cringes, formal beards,
Crisped hairs, and punctual cheats, do wriggle in
Their heads first, like a fox, to rooms of state,
Than the whole body follows.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Then they fill lordships, steal women's hearts: with them and their's the world runs round, yet these are square men still.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: There are none poor, but such as engross offices.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: None wise; but unthrifts, bankrupts, beggars, rascals.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: The hangman is a rare physician.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: That's not so good, it shall be granted.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: All the buzz of drugs, and minerals and simples,
blood-lettings, vomits, purges, or what else
Is conjured up by men of art, to gull
Liege-people, and rear golden piles, are trash
To a well-strong-wrought halter; there the gout,
The stone, yes and the melancholy devil,
Are cured in less time than a pair of minutes.
Build me a gallows in this very plot,
And I'll dispatch your business.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Fix the knot right under the left ear.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Sirrah, make ready.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Yet do not be too sudden, grant me leave,
To give a farewell to a creature long
Absented from me, 'tis a daughter (Sir)
Snatched from me in her youth, a handsome girl,
She comes to ask a blessing.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Pray where is she? I cannot see her yet.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: She makes more haste
In her quick prayers than her trembling steps,
Which many griefs have weakened.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Cruel man!
How canst thou rip a heart, that's cleft already
With injuries of time? whilst I am frantic,
Whilst throngs of rude divisions huddle on,
And do disrank my brains from peace, and sleep;
So long I am insensible of cares.
As balls of wildfire may be safely touched,
Not violently sundered, and thrown up;
So my distempered thoughts rest in their rage,
Not hurried in the air of repetition,
Or memory of my misfortunes past.
Then are my griefs struck home,
When they are reclaimed,
To their own pity of themselves — proceed;
what of your daughter now?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I cannot tell ye,
'Tis now out of my head again; my brains
Are crazy; I have scarce slept one sound sleep
These twelve months.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Alas poor man; canst thou imagine
To prosper in the task thou takest in hand,
By practising a cure upon my weakness,
And yet be no physician for thyself?
Go, go, turn over all thy books once more,
And learn to thrive in modesty; for impudence
Does least become a scholar. Thou art a fool,
A kind of learned fool.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I do confess it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: If thou canst wake with me, forget to eat,
Renounce the thought of greatness; tread on fate;
Sigh out a lamentable tale of things
Done long ago, and ill done; and when sighs
Are wearied, piece up what remains behind,
With weeping eyes, and hearts that bleed to death:
Thou shalt be a companion fit for me,
And we will sit together like true friends,
And never be divided. With what greediness
Do I hug my afflictions? there's no mirth
Which is not truly seasoned with some madness.
As for example. —

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: What new crotchet next?
There is so much sense in this wild distraction,
That I am almost out of my wits too,
To see and hear him: some few hours more
Spent here, would turn me apish, if not frantic.
In all the volumes thou hast turned, thou man
of knowledge, hast thou met with any rarity,
Worthy thy contemplation like to this?
The model of the heavens, the earth, the waters,
The harmony, and sweet consent of times,
Are not of such an excellence, in form
Of their creation, as the infinite wonder
That dwells within the compass of this face:
And yet I tell thee, scholar, under this
Well-ordered sign, is lodged such an obedience,
As will hereafter in another age,
Strike all comparison into a silence.
She had a sister too: but as for her,
If I were given to talk, I could describe
A pretty piece of goodness: let that pass —
We must be wise sometimes: what would you with her?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I with her! nothing by your leave, sir, I:
It is not my profession.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You are saucy,
And as I take it, scurvy in your sauciness,
To use no more respect — good soul, be patient:
We are a pair of things the world doth laugh at:
Yet be content, Cleophila; those clouds
Which bar the sun from shining on our miseries,
Will never be chased off till I am dead;
And than some charitable soul will take thee
Into protection. I am hasting on,
The time cannot be long.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I do beseech ye,
Sir, as you love your health, as you respect
My safety, let not passion overrule you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: It shall not, I am friends with all the world.
Get me some wine, to witness that I will be
An absolute good fellow, I will drink with thee.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Have you prepared his cup?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: 'Tis in readiness.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: By your leave, gallants, I come to speak with a young lady, as they say, the old Trojans daughter of the house.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Your business with my lady daughter, toss-pot?

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: Toss-pot? O base! Toss-pot?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Peace; dost not see in what case he is? I would do my own commendations to her; that's all.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Do, come my genius, we will quaff in wine
Till we grow wise.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: True nectar is divine.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: So, I am glad he is gone. Page, walk aside. Sweet beauty, I am sent ambassador from the mistress of my thoughts, to you, the mistress of my desires.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: So sir, I pray be brief.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: That you may know, I am not as they say, an animal; which is as they say, a kind of cokes, which is as the learned term, an ass, a puppy, a widgeon, a dolt, a noddy, a —

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: As you please.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Pardon me for that, it shall be as you please indeed. Forsooth I love to be courtly, and in fashion.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Well, to your embassy; what, or from whom?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Marry what is more than I know? for to know what's what, is to know what's what, and for what's what: but these are foolish figures, and to little purpose.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: From whom then are you sent?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: There you come to me again: oh, to be in the favour of great ladies, is as to say, as to be great in ladies' favours.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Good time a day t'ee; I can stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: By this light but you must, for now I come to't. The most excellent, most wise, most dainty, precious, loving, kind, sweet, intolerably fair lady Thamasta commends to your little hands, this letter of importance. By your leave, let me first kiss and then deliver it in fashion, to your own proper beauty.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: To me from her? 'tis strange; I dare peruse it.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Good, oh that I had not resolved to live a single life! Here's temptation able to conjure up a spirit with a witness. So so: she has read it.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Is't possible? Heaven, thou art great and bountiful.
Sir, I much thank your pains: and to the Princess,
Let my love, duty, service, be remembered.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: They shall madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: When we of hopes, or helps, are quite bereaven,
Our humble prayers have entrance into heaven.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: That's my opinion clearly and without doubt.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.p: The prince is thoroughly moved.

sp.speaker: Sophron.
sp.p: I never saw him so much distempered.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: What should this young man be,
Or whither can he be conveyed?

sp.speaker: Sophr.
sp.p: 'Tis to me a mystery, I understand it not.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Ye have consented all to work upon
The softness of my nature; but take heed:
Though I can sleep in silence, and look on
The mockery ye make of my dull patience;
Yet'ee shall know, the best of ye, that in me
There is a masculine, a stirring spirit;
which provoked, shall like a bearded comet
Set ye at gaze, and threaten horror.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Good sir. 'tis not your active wit or language,
Nor your grave politic wisdoms (Lords) shall dare
To checkmate and control my just commands.
Where is the youth your friend? is be found yet?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not to be heard of.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Fly then to the desert,
Where thou didst first encounter this fantastic,
This airy apparition; come no more
In sight: get ye all from me; he that stays,
Is not my friend.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: 'Tis strange.

sp.speaker: Aret. Soph.
sp.p: We must obey.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Some angry power, cheats with rare delusions,
My credulous sense: the very soul of reason
Is troubled in me — the physician
Presented a strange mask, the view of it
Puzzled my understanding: but the boy —
Rhetias, thou art acquainted with my griefs,
Parthenophill is lost, and I would see him;
For he is like to some thing I remember
A great while since, a long, long time ago.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I have been diligent (Sir) to pry into every corner for discovery, but cannot meet with him: there is some trick I am confident.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: There is, there is some practice, sleight or plot.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: I have apprehended a fair wench, in an odd
Private lodging in the city, as like the youth
In face, as can by possibility be discerned.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: How Rhetias!

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: If it be not Parthenophill in long coats,
'Tis a spirit in his likeness; answer
I can get none from her; you shall see her.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: The young man in disguise upon my life,
To steal out of the land.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I'll send him t'ee.
sp.stage: Enter Eroclea in woman's attire, and listens.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Do, do my Rhetias. As there is by nature
In every thing created contrariety:
So likewise is there unity and league
Between them in their kind; but man, the abstract
Of all perfection, which the workmanship
Of heaven hath modelled, in himself contains
Passions of several quality, the music
Of man's fair composition best accords,
When 'tis in consort, not in single strains.
My heart has been untuned these many months,
Wanting her presence, in whose equal love
True harmony consisted; living here
We are heaven's bounty all, but fortune's exercise.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Minutes are numbered by the fall of sands;
As by an hourglass, the span of time
Doth waste us to our graves, and we look on it.
An age of pleasures revelled out, comes home
At last, and ends in sorrow, but the life
Weary of riot, numbers every sand,
Wailing in sighs, until the last drop down,
So to conclude calamity in rest.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: What echo yields a voice to my complaints?
Can I be nowhere private?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Let the substance
As suddenly be hurried from your eyes,
as the vain sound can pass your ear,
If no impression of a troth vowed yours,Kneels.
Retain a constant memory.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Stand up; 'tis not the figure stamped upon thy cheeks,
The cozenage of thy beauty, grace, or tongue,
Can draw from me a secret, that hath been
The only jewel of my speechless thoughts.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: I am so worn away with fears and sorrows,
So wintered with the tempests of affliction,
That the bright sun of your life-quickening presence
Hath scarce one beam of force, to warm again
That spring of cheerful comfort, which youth once
Apparelled in fresh looks.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Cunning impostor,
Untruth hath made thee subtle in thy trade:
If any neighbouring greatness hath seduced
A freeborn resolution, to attempt
Some bolder act of treachery, by cutting
My weary days off. Wherefore (Cruel-mercy)
Hast thou assumed a shape, that would make treason
A piety, guilt pardonable, bloodshed
As holy as the sacrifice of peace?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: The incense of my love-desires, are flamed
Upon an altar of more constant proof.
Sir, oh sir, turn me back into the world,
Command me to forget my name, my birth,
My father's sadness, and my death alive,
If all remembrance of my faith hath found
A burial, without pity in your scorn.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: My scorn (Disdainful boy) shall soon unweave
The web thy art hath twisted: cast thy shape off,
Disrobe the mantle of a feigned sex,
And so I may be gentle; as thou art,
there's witchcraft in thy language, in thy face,
In thy demeanours; turn, turn from me (Prithee)
For my belief is armed else. Yet (Fair subtlety)
Before we part (For part we must) be true,
Tell me thy country.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Ha: thy father.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Meleander.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Hast a name?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: A name of misery, the unfortunate Eroclea.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: There is danger
In this seducing counterfeit, great goodness!
Hath honesty and virtue left the time?
Are we become so impious, that to tread
The path of impudence, is law and justice?
Thou vizard of a beauty ever sacred,
Give me thy name.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Whilst I was lost to memory,
Parthenophill did shroud my shame in change
Of sundry rare misfortunes: but since now
I am, before I die, returned to claim
A convoy to my grave, I must not blush
To let prince Pallador (If I offend,)
Know when he dooms me, that he dooms Eroclea.
I am that woeful maid.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Join not too fast
Thy penance, with the story of my sufferings.
So dwelled simplicity with virgin truth;
So martyrdom and holiness are twins,
As innocence and sweetness on thy tongue.
But let me by degrees collect my senses,
I may abuse my trust. Tell me, what air
Hast thou perfumed, since tyranny first ravished
the contract of our hearts?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Dear sir, in Athens have I been buried.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Buried! Right, as I
In Cyprus. — come to trial, if thou beest
Eroclea, in my bosom I can find thee.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: As I, prince Palador, in mine: this gift
His bounty blessed me with, the only physic
My solitary cares have hourly took,
To keep me from despair.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: We are but fools
To trifle in disputes, or vainly struggle
With that eternal mercy which protects us.
Come home, home to my heart, thou banished-peace,
My ecstasy of joys would speak in passion,
But that I would not lose that part of man,
Which is reserved to entertain content.
Eroclea, I am thine; oh let me seize thee
As my inheritance. Hymen shall now
Set all his torches burning, to give light
Throughout this land, new settled in thy welcome.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: You are still gracious. Sir, how I have lived,
By what means been conveyed, by what preserved,
By what returned; Rhetias, my trusty servant,
Directed by the wisdom of my uncle,
The good Sophronos, can inform at large.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Enough, in stead of music, every night
To make our sleeps delightful, thou shalt close
Our weary eyes with some part of thy story.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: O but my father!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Fear not: to behold
Eroclea safe, will make him young again;
It shall be our first task. Blush sensual follies,
a castaway, a poor despised maid,
Only for me to hope was almost sin,
Yet troth I never tempted him.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Chide not the grossness of my trespass (Lovely sweetness)
In such an humble language, I have smarted
Already in the wounds, my pride hath made
Upon thy sufferings. Henceforth 'tis in you
To work my happiness.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Call any service
Of mine a debt, for such it is; the letter
You lately sent me, in the blessed contents
It made me privy to, hath largely quit
Every suspicion of your grace or goodness.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Let me embrace thee with a sister's love,
A sister's love, Cleophila: for should
My brother henceforth study to forget
The vows that he hath made thee, I would ever
Solicit thy deserts.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: We must have entrance.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Must? Who are they say, must? you are unmannerly.
Brother is't you, and you too, sir?

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Your ladyship has had a time of
Scolding to your humour:
Does the storm hold still?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Never fell a shower
More seasonably gentle on the barren
Parched thirsty earth, than showers of courtesy
Have from this Princess been distilled on me,
To make my growth in quiet of my mind
Secure and lasting.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p: You may both believe that I was not uncivil.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: Pish, I know her spirit, and her envy.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Now in troth, sir,
Pray credit me, I do not use to swear ▪
The virtuous Princess hath in words and carriage
Been kind, so overkind, that I do blush:
I am not rich enough in thanks sufficient
For her unequalled bounty. — my good cousin,
I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: It shall be granted.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: That no time, no persuasion, no respects
Of jealousies past, present, or hereafter
By possibility to be conceived,
Draw you from that sincerity and pureness
Of love, which you have oftentimes protested
To this great worthy lady she deserves
A duty more, then what the ties of marriage
Can claim, or warrant: be for ever hers,
As she is yours, and heaven increase your comforts.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Clophila hath played the churchman's part,
I'll not forbid the banes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Are you consented?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I have one task in charge first, which concerns me.
Brother, be not more cruel than this lady,
She hath forgiven my follies, so may you:
Her youth, her beauty, innocence, discretion,
Without additions of estate or birth,
Are dower for a prince indeed. You loved her;
For sure you swore you did: else if you did not
Here fix your heart, and thus resolve, if now
You miss this heaven on earth, you cannot find
In any other choice ought but a hell.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: The ladies are turned lawyers, and plead handsomely
Their clients cases. I am an easy judge,
And so shalt thou be Menaphon. I give thee
my sister for a wife; a good one, friend.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Lady, will you confirm the gift?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: The errors of my mistaken judgement being lost,
To your remembrance, I shall ever strive
In my obedience to deserve your pity.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My love, my care, my all.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: What rests for me?
I'm still a bachelor: sweet maid, resolve me,
May I yet call you mine?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: My lord Amethus,
Blame not my plainness, I am young and simple,
And have not any power to dispose
Mine own will without warrant from my father:
That purchased, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p: It shall suffice me.

div.stage: Enter Cuculus, Pelias, Trollio and Grilla plucked in by 'em.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Revenge, I must have revenge; I will have revenge bitter and abominable revenge; I will have revenge. This unfashionable mongrel, this linsey-woolsey of mortality by this hand, mistress, this she-rogue is drunk, and clapper-clawed me without any reverence to my person, or good garments, why d'ye not speak, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Some certain blows have passed, an't like your highness.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: Some few knocks of friendship, some love-toys, some cuffs in kindness, or so.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: I'll turn him away, he shall be my master no longer.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Is this your she-page, Cuculus? 'tis a boy, sure.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: A boy, an arrant boy in long coats.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p:
He has mumbled his nose, that 'tis as big as a
great cod piece.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: O thou cock vermin of iniquity.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Pelias, take hence the wag and school him for't.
For your part, servant, I'll entreat the prince
To grant you some fit place about his wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: Ever after a bloody nose do I dream of good luck.
I horribly thank your ladyship.
Whilst I'm in office, the old garb shall again
Grow in request, and tailors shall be men.
Come Trollio, help to wash my face, prithee.

sp.speaker: Trol.
sp.p: Yes, and to scour it too. —

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: The prince and Princess are at hand, give over your amorous dialogues. Most honoured lady, henceforth forbear your sadness: are you ready to practise your instructions?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I have studied
My part with care, and will perform it (Rhetias)
With all the skill I can.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'll pass my word for her.

div.stage: Flourish. enter prince, sophronus, Aretius, and Eroclea.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Thus princes should be circled with a guard
Of truly noble friends, and watchful subjects.
O Rhetias, thou art just; the youth thou toldest me.
That lived at Athens, is returned at last
To her own fortunes, and contracted love .

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: My knowledge made me sure of my report, sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Eroclea, clear thy fears, when the sun shines,
Clouds must not dare to muster in the sky,
Nor shall they here — why do they kneel? Stand up,
The day and place is privileged.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Your presence, great sir, makes every room a sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Wherefore does this young virgin use such circumstance,
In duty to us? Rise.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: 'Tis I must raise her.
Forgive me, sister, I have been too private,
In hiding from your knowledge any secret
That should have been in common twixt our souls:
But I was ruled by council.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: That I show myself a girl (Sister) and bewray
Joy in too soft a passion 'fore all these,
I hope you cannot blame me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: We must part:
The sudden meeting of these two fair rivulets
With th' island of our arms, Cleophila,
The custom of thy piety hath built
Even to thy younger years a monument
Of memorable fame; some great reward
Must wait on thy desert.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: The prince speaks t'ee, niece.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Chat low, I pray; let's about our business.
The good old man awakes: my lord, withdraw;
Rhetias, let's settle here the coach.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Away then.

div.stage: Soft music. Enter Melander (In a coach) his hair and beard trim, habit and gown changed. Rhetias and Corax, and boy that sings.

lg.head: The song.
lg.l: Fly hence, shadows, that do keep
Yet the heart doth ever waken
Thoughts, chained up in busy snares
Love and griefs are so expressed,
As they rather sigh than rest.
Fly hence, shadows, that do keep

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Where am I? Ha? What sounds are these? 'tis day, sure.
O, I have slept belike: 'tis but the foolery
Of some beguiling dream. So, so, I will not
Trouble the play of my delighted fancy
But dream my dream out.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Morrow to your lordship:
You took a jolly nap, and slept it soundly.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Away, beast, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: O, by your leave, sir.
I must be bold to raise ye, else your physic
Will turn to further sickness.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Physic, bear-leech?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes physic, you are mad.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Trollio, Cleophila.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Sir, I am here.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I know thee, Rhetias, prithee rid the room
Of this tormenting noise. He tells me, sirrah.
I have taken physic, Rhetias, physic, physic.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Sir true, you have; and this most learned scholar
Applied t'ee. O you were in dangerous plight
Before he took ye hand.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: These things are drunk,
Directly drunk. Where did you get your liquor?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I never saw a body in the wane
Of age, so over spread with several sorts
Of such diseases as the strength of youth
Would groan under and sink.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: The more your glory in the miraculous cure.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Bring me the cordial
Prepared for him to take after his sleep,
'Twill do him good at heart.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I hope it will, sir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What dost think I am, that thou shouldst fiddle
So much upon my patience? Fool, the weight
Of my disease sits on my heart so heavy,
That all the hands of art cannot remove
One grain to ease my grief. If thou couldst poison
My memory, or wrap my senses up
Into a dulness, hard and cold as flints?
If thou couldst make me walk, speak, eat and laugh
Without a sense or knowledge of my faculties,
Why then perhaps at marts thou mightst make benefit
Of such an antic motion, and get credit
From credulous gazers, but not profit me.
Study to gull the wise; I am too simple
To be wrought on.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I'll burn my books (Old man)
But I will do thee good, and quickly too.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: Most honoured lord Meleander, our great master,
prince Palador of Cyprus, hath by me
Sent you this patent, in which is contained
Not only confirmation of the honours
You formerly enjoyed, but the addition
Of the marshalship of Cyprus, and ere long
He means to visit you. Excuse my haste,
I must attend the prince. —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: There's one pill works.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Dost know that spirit? 'tis a grave familiar,
And talked I know not what.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He's like, methinks , the prince his tutor, Aretus.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Yes, yes; it may be I have seen such a formality;
No matter where, or when.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: The prince hath sent ye
(My lord) this staff of office, and withal
Salutes you grand commander of the ports
Throughout his principalities. He shortly
Will visit you himself: I must attend him. —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: D'ye feel your physic stirring yet?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: A devil is a rare juggler, and can cheat the eye,
But not corrupt the reason in the throne
Of a pure soul. — another? I will stand thee,
Be what thou canst, I care not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: From the prince, dear brother, I present you this rich relic,
A jewel he hath long worn in his bosom:
Henceforth he bade me say, he does beseech you
to call him son, for he will call you father.
It is an honour (Brother) that a subject
Cannot but entertain with thankful prayers.
Be moderate in your loys, he will in person
Confirm my errand, but commands my service.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: What hope now of your cure?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Stay, stay — what earthquakes
Roll in my flesh? here's prince, and prince and prince;
Prince upon prince: the dotage of my sorrow's
Revels in magic of ambitious scorn,
Be they enchantments deadly (As the grave)
I'll look upon 'em: patent, staff, and relic
To the last first. Round me, ye guarding ministers
And ever keep me waking till the cliffs
That over hang my sight fall off, and leave
These hollow spaces to be crammed with dust.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis time I see to fetch the cordial. Prithee
Sit down: I'll instantly be here again —

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Good, give me leave, I will sit down indeed:
Here's company enough for me to prate to,

sp.speaker: Eroclea.
sp.l: 'Tis the same, the cunning artsman
Faltered not in a line. Could he have fashioned
A little hollow space here, and blown breath
To have made it move, and whisper, 't had been excellent.
But faith, 'tis well, 'tis very well as 'tis.
Passing, most passing well.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: The sovereign greatness,
Who, by commission from the powers of heaven,
Sways both this land and us, our gracious prince,
By me presents you (Sir) with this large bounty,
a gift more precious to him then his birthright.
Here let your cares take end; now set at liberty
Your long imprisoned heart, and welcome home
The solace of your soul, too long kept from you.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Dear sir, you know me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Yes, thou art my daughter:
My eldest blessing. Know thee? Why Eroclea,
I never did forget thee in thy absence.
Poor soul, how dost?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: The best of my well-being consists in yours.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Stand up: the gods who hitherto
Have kept us both alive, preserve thee ever.

sp.speaker: Cleophila ▪
sp.l: I thank thee and the prince,
I thank thee too, Eroclea, that thou wouldst
In pity of my age, take so much pains
To live, till I might once more look upon thee,
Before I broke my heart: oh 'twas a piece
Of piety and duty unexampled.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: The goodman relisheth his comforts strangely,
The sight doth turn me child.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: I have not words that can express my joys.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Nor I: yet let us gaze on one another freely,
And surfeit with our eyes; let me be plain,
If I should speak as much as I should speak,
I should talk of a thousand things at once,
And all of thee, of thee (My child) of thee:
My tears like ruffling winds locked up in caves,
Do bustle for a vent — on tother side,
To fly out into mirth were not so comely.
Come hither, let me kiss thee — with a pride,
Strength, courage, and fresh blood, which now thy presence
Hath stored me with, I kneel before their altars,
whose sovereignty kept guard about thy safety.
Ask, ask thy sister (Prithee) she'll tell thee
How I have been much mad.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Much discontented,
Shunning all means that might procure him comfort.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: Heaven has at last been gracious.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: So say I but wherefore crop thy words in such a sloth,
As if thou wert afraid to mingle truth.
With thy misfortunes? Understand me thoroughly,
I would not have thee to report at large
From point to point, a journal of thy absence:
'Twill take up too much time, I would securely
Engross the little remnant of my life,
That thou might'st every day be telling somewhat,
Which might convey me to my rest with comfort.
Let me be me, how we parted first:
Puzzles my faint remembrance — but soft,

sp.speaker: Cleophila,
sp.l: Thou toldst me, that the prince
Sent me this present.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: From this own fair hands I did receive my sister.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: To requite him, we will not dig his father's grave anew,
Although the mention of him much concerns
The business we inquire of — as I said,
We parted in a hurry at the court,
I to this castle, after made my jail.
But whither thou, dear heart?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Now they fall to't, I looked for this.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: I by my uncle's care (Sophronos ▪ my good uncle) suddenly was like a sailor's boy conveyed a shipboard that every night.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: A policy quick and strange.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: The ship was bound for Corinth, whither first
Attended only with your servant Rhetias,
and all fit necessaries, we arrived:
From thence in habit of a youth we journeyed
To Athens, where till our return of late,
Have we lived safe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: O what a thing is man,
To bandy factions of distempered passions,
Against the sacred providence above him?
Here in the legend of thy two years exile,
Rare pity and delight are sweetly mixed,
And still thou wert a boy.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.p: So I obeyed my uncle's wise command.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: 'Twas safely carried, I humbly thank thy fate.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: If earthly treasures
Are poured in plenty down from heaven on mortals;
They reign amongst those oracles, that flow
In schools of sacred knowledge; such is Athens:
Yet Athens was to me but a fair prison:
The thoughts of you, my sister, country, fortunes,
And something of the prince, barred all contents,
Which else might ravish sense: for had not, Rhetias,
Been always comfortable to me, certainly
Things had gone worse.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Speak low Eroclea;
That something of the prince bears danger in it:
Yet thou hast travailed (Wench) for such endowments,
As might create a prince a wife fit for him,
Had he the world to guide: but touch not there;
How cam'st thou home?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Sir, with your noble savour,
Kissing your hand first, that point I can answer.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Honest, right honest Rhetias.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Your grave brother
Perceived with what a hopeless love his son,
lord Menaphon, too eagerly pursued
Thamasta, cousin to our present prince;
And to remove the violence of affection,
Sent him to Athens, where for twelve months space
Your daughter, my young lady and her cousin
Enjoyed each others griefs, till by his father
The lord Sophronos we were all called home.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Enough, enough, the world shall henceforth witness
My thankfulness to heaven, and those people
Who have been pitiful to me and mine.
Lend me a looking-glass — how now? How came I
So courtly in fresh raiments?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Here's the glass, sir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I'm in the trim too. — oh Cleophila,
This was the goodness of thy care and cunning. —
Whence comes this noise?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: The prince my lord in person.

div.stage: Enter prince, Sophronos, Aretas, Amethus, Menaphon, Thamasta, Corax, Kala.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Ye shall not kneel to us; rise all, I charge ye:
Father, you wrong your age, henceforth my arms
And heart shall be your guard; we have o'erheard
All passages of your united loves.
Be young again, Meleander, live to number
An happy generation, and die old
In comforts as in years. The offices
And honours which I late on thee conferred,
Are not fantastic bounties, but thy merit;
Enjoy them liberally.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: My tears must thank ye, for my tongue cannot.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I have kept my promise, and given you a sure cordial.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O, a rare one.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Good man, we both have shared enough of sadness:
Though thine has tasted deeper of th'extreme;
Let us forget it henceforth. Where's the picture
I sent ye? Keep it, 'tis a counterfeit,
And in exchange of that, I cease on this,
The real substance: with this other hand
I give away before her father's face
His younger joy, Cleophila, to thee
Cousin Amethus: take her, and be to her
More than a father, a deserving husband.
Thus robbed of both thy children in a minute,
Thy cares are taken off.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: My brains are dulled;
I am entranced, and know not what you mean:
Great, gracious sir, alas, why do you mock me?
I am a weak old man, so poor and feeble,
That my untoward joints can scarcely creep
Unto the grave, where I must seek my rest.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Eroclea was you know, contracted mine;
Cleophila, my cousins by consent
Of both their hearts: we both now claim our own;
It only rests in you to give a blessing
For confirmation.

sp.speaker: Rhetias.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis truth and justice.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The gods that lent ye to me, bless your vows:
Oh children, children, pay your prayers to heaven,
For they have showed much mercy. But Sophronos,
Thou art my brother: I can say no more:
A good, good brother.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Leave the rest to time.
Cousin Thamasta, I must give you too:
She's thy wife, Menaphon. Rhetias, for thee
and Corax, I have more than common thanks.
On, to the temple; there all solemn rites
Performed, a general feast shall be proclaimed.
The lover's melancholy hath found cure;
Sorrows are changed to bride-songs. So they thrive,
Whom fate in spite of storms hath kept alive.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: To be too confident, is as unjust
In any work, as too much to distrust;
Who from the laws of study have not swerved,
Know, begged applauses never were deserved.
We must submit to censure: so doth he,
Whose hours begotten this issue; yet being free
For his part, if he have not pleased you, then
In this kind, he'll not trouble you again.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
